subject: statistics
statementHtml: Consider a dataset of exam scores with mean 80 and standard deviation 5. Conduct a one-sample t-test to determine if the sample mean is significantly different from the population mean.
hints: Recall that the null hypothesis states there's no significant difference between the sample mean and the population mean.
Think about how you can use the sample standard deviation to estimate the population standard deviation.
Remember to calculate the t-statistic and compare it to a critical value or p-value.
solutionHtml:
To conduct the one-sample t-test, we first need to calculate the sample mean, which is 82. Then, we can calculate the t-statistic:

\n\[t = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu}{s/\sqrt{n}}\]\n

Next, we compare the calculated t-statistic to a critical value or p-value.

",

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Perform a one-sample t-test to determine if the average exam score of 25 students is significantly different from the population mean of 80.
hints: The null hypothesis states that the true average exam score is equal to 80.
Use the sample standard deviation and sample size to calculate the t-statistic.
Compare the calculated t-statistic to the critical value from a t-distribution table or calculator.
solutionHtml:
Solution:

The sample mean is 82, and the sample standard deviation is 4.5. Using these values, we calculate the t-statistic as follows:

\[t = \frac{\bar{x} - \mu}{s / \sqrt{n}} = \frac{82 - 80}{4.5 / \sqrt{25}} = 2.33

Next, we compare this value to the critical t-value from a t-distribution table or calculator with 24 degrees of freedom (n-1). Let's say the critical value is approximately 2.06.

If our calculated t-statistic (2.33) is greater than the critical value (2.06), we reject the null hypothesis and conclude that the average exam score is significantly different from the population mean.

",

subject: statistics
statementHtml: Consider a dataset of exam scores from students who have been taking a new teaching method. You want to test whether the average score has increased compared to last year's scores. Assuming normality and equal variances, perform a one-sample t-test.
hints: Start by calculating the sample mean and standard deviation.
Compare your calculated value to the known population mean (last year's average).
Don't forget to consider the degrees of freedom for your t-statistic.
solutionHtml: To perform the one-sample t-test, first calculate the sample mean \\(x̄\\) and standard deviation \\(s\\): \\[x̄ = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n x_i, \quad s = \sqrt{\frac{1}{n-1} \sum_{i=1}^n (x_i - x̄)^2}.\\] Then, calculate the test statistic \\(t\\) as: \\[t = \frac{x̄ - μ_0}{s / \sqrt{n}}.\\] Finally, compare your calculated value to the critical t-value from a t-distribution table or calculator for \\(n-1\\) degrees of freedom.",
answerShort: Reject the null hypothesis if |t| > t_{crit} and do not reject otherwise." },

subject: statistics
title: One-Sample T-Test
statementHtml: Suppose we want to test whether the average height of students in a class is different from the known population mean of 175 cm. We have a random sample of n = 25 student heights with sample mean x̄ = 172 cm and sample standard deviation s = 5 cm. Use a one-sample t-test to determine whether the sample mean is significantly different from the population mean.
hints: Think about how you would compare the sample mean to the population mean if you didn't know the population standard deviation.
The t-statistic will be calculated using the sample mean and standard deviation, as well as the known population mean.
solutionHtml:
To perform the one-sample t-test, we first calculate the test statistic:

\[t = rac{ ar{x} - \mu}{s/\sqrt{n}}.\]

Next, we compare this value to a critical value from the t-distribution with n-1 degrees of freedom.

If the calculated t-statistic is greater than the critical value, we reject the null hypothesis that the sample mean is equal to the population mean.

",

subject: statistics
title: One-Sample T-Test Problem
statementHtml: Consider a random sample of size n from a normally distributed population with unknown mean μ. We want to test the null hypothesis that the true mean is equal to a known value μ0, against the alternative hypothesis that it's not. The sample mean is x̄ and the sample standard deviation is s. Use a one-sample t-test to determine if there's sufficient evidence to reject the null hypothesis.
hints: Check the assumptions of the t-test, including normality and equal variances.
Calculate the test statistic and compare it to the critical value from a t-distribution table or calculator.
Consider using software like R or Python to calculate the p-value and perform the test.
solutionHtml:
First, we need to check the assumptions of the t-test. Since our sample size is moderate, we can assume normality if our data looks roughly normally distributed.

Next, we'll calculate the test statistic:

\[t = \frac{x̄ - μ0}{s / \sqrt{n}}\]

We can then compare this value to the critical value from a t-distribution table or calculator. If our calculated value is more extreme than the critical value, we reject the null hypothesis.

If you're using software, you can calculate the p-value and perform the test directly.

",
answerShort: Reject the null hypothesis if |t| > 2.045 (for a two-tailed test) or use software to determine the p-value." },
